awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Agenda Generality and Behavior in Social Network Interactions about COVID-19
awd_abstract_narration:
The same types of social networks that transmit the COVID-19 disease may be leveraged to spread healthy norms and positive behaviors. This research gathers important, time-sensitive data to understand the conditions under which digital social networks can influence health behaviors relevant to the COVID-19 pandemic and how to reduce negative social influences in digital environments. At a time when people spend unprecedented amounts of time on digital networks, public health strategies deployed in these networks may shape the health and social outcomes of Americans in the next 12 months. This research advances understanding of these public health strategies.

The project’s theory is that discussing either general or specific issues (e.g., curbing COVID-19 disease or wearing a mask) can have important consequences on the spread of risky attitudes and behaviors through a network. The research entails (a) an ecological study of Twitter and Instagram networks and (b) experiments manipulating the mix of healthy and risky behaviors promoted in the network and the focus of the discussion on either general or specific issues. The project generates public health recommendations and algorithms to improve health discussions on social media. The investigators use a dynamic panel data model to predict individual behavior from the individual’s own attitudes and own past behaviors as well as the behaviors of other members of their network. The research team uses graph convolutional networks both to capture richer network aspects and to model sparse networks.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award funded two main studies. These studies were designed to test the mechanisms and real-world impacts of social media messaging as applied to behaviors and attitudes toward the COVID-19 pandemic. The first study we describe in this report analyzes how different messages impact individuals' attitudes. The second study described in this report analyzes the determinants of retweeting healthy and risky tweets by looking at the norms of users' social networks. 

  The first study consisted of 20 experiments, testing the impact of social media messaging on individuals' attitudes and intentions. We hypothesized that messages that either support or oppose an attitude. One main experiment showed a significant interaction between participants' message advocacy (healthy vs. risky) and message type (behavioral vs. attitudinal). Wherein, participants indicated that they favored COVID-19 prevention behaviors (i.e., wearing a mask, taking a COVID test, etc.) to a greater extent when they read healthy behavioral messages than risky behavioral messages on a 7-point Likert scale. There was no statistical difference in participants attitudes between reading the healthy and risky attitudinal messages.  

In another main experiment of this study, we analyzed differences between positive and negative messages across attitudinal and behavioral messages. This analysis showed that positive messages led to significantly more positive attitudes in both cases. However, the interaction implies that the difference between the positive and negative messages is larger for the behavioral messages than the attitudinal messages. 

The second study run under this award analyzed determinants of healthy and risky tweets and retweets, with regard to COVID-19. This study analyzed 30,868,992 tweets from a sample of 571 Twitter networks that engaged in discussions about COVID-19 from March 1st, 2020 to August 31st, 2020. Of those sampled, 100 individual users were selected based on the ratio of the total pertinent hashtags used by the user and the total pertinent hashtags used by their group. The findings of this study show that the most important determinant of an individual user's healthy retweets is their neighbors' healthy posts. Further, the most important determinant of an individual user's risky retweets is their neighbors' risky posts. 

In addition, this study found that a network's norms contribute to the spread of healthy social media messages. In particular, we find that networks with healthier norms (i.e., neighbors the ratio of their healthy hashtags to all hashtags posted by the neighbors in the network is at least 75 percent) were more strongly associated with a higher number of retweets than in balanced networks (i.e., neighbors that the ratio of their healthy hashtags to all hashtags posted by the neighbors in the network is around 50 percent) or networks with riskier norms (i.e., neighbors that the ratio of their risky hashtags to all hashtags posted by the neighbors in the network is less than 25 percent).  

Overall, the work done under this award has contributed to our fields understanding of how different social media messaging styles impact attitudes, and the importance of norms in social networks. As academia continues to explore social media as a potential medium for behavioral and attitudinal interventions, we believe that this work can provide a framework for analyzing and harnessing social media's role in issues similar to the COVID-19 pandemic.
